metadata.title: Spray Drying of Folic Acid within Nano-Emulsions; Optimization by Taguchi Approach

sections.text:
Research over recent decades has shown that inadequate folate concentrations may contribute to some disorders. Cereal flours have been a primary candidate for fortification by folic acid as they are consumed by most of the people but the main obstacle is destruction of this vitamin by the process and environmental deteriorating factors. So, it can be nano-encapsulated for protection and efficient delivery. Our main goal was to find the optimum conditions in spray drying of pectin-WPC (Whey Protein Concentrate) double emulsions containing folic acid. Five independent variables including pectin and WPC content, dispersed phase content, pH, and surfactant type of Span and PGPR (Poly Glycerol Poly Ricinoleate) were considered along with water activity (aw) and bulk density as the main responses. The experiment design was performed by Taguchi approach and 16 treatments were determined. The grand average of aw and bulk density for folic acid powders was approximately 0.371 and 343 kg/m 3 , respectively. The main effect analysis with Taguchi technique revealed that pectin content was the most important factor affecting aw (39.5%) and WPC had the minimum influence (6%). In terms of bulk density, it was found that the most important parameter was WPC (29.6%)
and the minimum influence was related to surfactant system (8.1%). Finally, optimum conditions were determined as 0.5% pectin, 4.0% WPC, 10% dispersed phase, pH=8, with a PGPR micro-emulsion which resulted in aw=0.229, and 1.5% pectin, 8.0% WPC, 10% dispersed phase, pH=9, with a PGPR nano-emulsion which resulted in density=245.45 kg/m 3 for folic acid powders.
KEYWORDS: Spray drying; Folic acid; Optimization; Taguchi.
1. INTRODUCTION
Many researchers have investigated delivery systems to protect the vitamins from detrimental effects. The W/O micro-emulsion as a delivery system can increase the antioxidative effects, bioavailability and solubility of hydrophilic bioactive vitamins. [1,2] On the other hand, emulsification of W/O micro-emulsions within an aqueous phase containing hydrophilic emulsifiers could lead to production of water in oil in water (W/O/W) double emulsions. As a result, the hydrophilic bioactive compounds are entrapped in the inner aqueous phase of W/O/W emulsions which have shown greater stability in gastrointestinal fluid (GIT), high stability with controllable release in food formulations and enhanced bioavailability. [3-5] However, thermodynamic instability and diffusion of hydrosoluble vitamins through the oil layers limits usage of W/O/W multiple emulsions in food systems. [6-8]
Low or inadequate folate concentrations may contribute to some malfunctions and disorders. [9] In many countries, particularly the developing populations, people suffer
from folate deficiency. Cereal flours have been a primary candidate for fortification as they are consumed by most of the people. [10-12] Fortification with folic acid has some possible limitations since added vitamin may be lost during processing and handling due to its high sensitivity to heat, oxidation, pH, and other environmental conditions. Due to its properties as a vitamin and medicinal compound, folic acid must be protected against environmental conditions and should have a controlled release. [13] There are several ways to encapsulate and protect hydrophilic bioactive components such as folic acid including liposomes, multiple emulsions, solid fat particles, biopolymer complexes, niosomes, and biologically derived systems. [14,15]
Emulsions with optimum conditions such as smaller droplets and appropriate rheological properties could result in high stability of W/O/W multiple emulsions. [16,17] Whey proteins have been widely investigated as hydrophilic emulsifiers for W/O/W emulsions. [15,18-20] Also, it has been shown that whey proteins can be used as an excellent functional agent in food formulations. Faridi et al (2015) showed pectin combined with WPC could create an elastic and aggregated layer around oil droplets, which helps to improve stability of encapsulated saffron bioactive components in W/O/W multiple emulsions against processing (e.g., spray drying process). Also it has been proved that functional properties (like antioxidant activity, solubility, gelation, and foaming behavior) of whey proteins would improve when combined with pectin. [20-23]
Our main goal in this work was monitoring physical properties of folic acid spray dried powders as a function of pectin and WPC content, dispersed phase content, and pH of
external aqueous phase along with surfactant type, and the optimum conditions to make powders with the lowest water activity and bulk density which was determined by Taguchi’s robust design methodology. Taguchi is a process-product optimization method based on different steps of planning, conducting, and evaluating results of matrix experiments to determine the best level of control factors on characteristic properties and hence optimal conditions for any complex process. [24,25] It has been used in many areas of manufacturing since the 1960s, with many discrete product engineering and manufacturing companies using it to great effect. This technique is an alternative to standard full factorial designs. Since it reduces the number of experiments, it is easier to use, faster and at the same time, accurate and reliable, saving time and cost. [26,27] Taguchi method can determine the experimental conditions having the best effect on the desired characteristics (optimal conditions).
Although encapsulated powders have been produced for coating of different bioactive compounds, [28-30] studies about usage of nano-carrier complex biopolymers with controllable release of folic acid from W/O/W multiple emulsions has not been performed. In the present study, with the aim of improving powder properties of folic acid in W/O/W emulsion formulations by applying complexes of WPC/pectin in the outer phase, we applied for the first time a Taguchi approach.
2. MATERIALS AND METHODS
Folic acid (purity>97%, molecular weight 441.4) and Span 80 (sorbitan mono oleate) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. (St. Louis, MO), and Merck Chemicals Co.
(Germany), respectively. PGPR (polyglycerol polyricinoleate, E476)) was kindly donated by Palsgaard, Denmark. Canola oil was purchased from a local market. Double distilled water was used for preparing all emulsions. Whey protein concentrate (80% protein) and maltodextrin were obtained from Arla (Denmark) and Qinhuangdao starch Co. (DE 16- 20, China), respectively. Citrus pectin with a degree of methyl esterification of 71.1% and galacturonic acid >65% was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. All other chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade.

sections.heading: 2.1. Production Of Primary Emulsions
sections.text: W/O micro-emulsions were prepared by spontaneous emulsification according to our previously used procedures for making W1/O emulsions. [31] Briefly, aqueous phase was prepared by mixing folic acid solution and Span 80 or PGPR using a magnetic stirrer (IKA, Germany) at 1000 rpm and then added drop wise to oil phase while magnetically stirring. For nano-emulsions, the same procedure was applied except replacing magnetic stirrer with a rotor-stator homogenizer (Ultra-Turrax, IKA, Germany) at 10,000 rpm for 5 min. The formulation was composed of 76:12:12% of canola oil, surfactant (Span or PGPR), and folic acid solution (with a concentration of 3 mg FA/mL in phosphate buffer at pH= 9), respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation Of Double Emulsions
sections.text:
Pectin powder was dissolved in boiling deionized water to prepare 100 g pectin solutions with concentrations of 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0 % w/w. At the same time, different aqueous solutions of whey protein concentrate were prepared by dispersing required amounts of
WPC powder (as shown in Table 1) into deionized water to obtain 100 g solutions containing 0.02% sodium azide as an antimicrobial agent. Solutions were gently stirred for at least 30 min on a magnetic stirrer. Then, pectin and WPC solutions were mixed together and stored overnight at room temperature for complete hydration of biopolymers. For increasing dry matter of the feed into spray dryer, 30 g maltodextrin solution with a total solids of 50% w/w (Brix= 50) was added into mixed biopolymer solutions and their pH was adjusted to predetermined pH values (Table 1) using HCL and NaOH (0.1 M).
W1/O/W2 emulsions were prepared in two-step, according to Faridi et al., (2015), briefly:
(a) Frist, primary W1/O nano-emulsions were produced by the formulation procedure described in section 2.1. (b) W1/O/W2 double emulsions were prepared by gradually adding W1/O nanoemulsions into the outer aqueous phase of mixed biopolymer solutions (WPC/pectin/maltodextrin) while blending by a homogenizer (Heidolph Silentcrusher, Germany) at 12000 rpm for 5 minutes at 10 o C, and then these coarse emulsions were further emulsified using mentioned homogenizer (15000 rpm for 8 minutes at 10 o C). Dispersed phase volume fraction (DPVF) for double emulsions shows the volume of primary emulsion (W1/O) divided by volume of total double emulsion (W1/O/W2) multiplied by 100. The composition of W1/O/W2 multiple emulsions is given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Spray Drying Of Double Emulsions
sections.text: The infeed double emulsions were transformed into encapsulated powders in a lab spray drier (Model SP1500, Fanyuan Instrument Co., Shanghai, China) equipped with a pressure air atomizing nozzle at 2.5 bar air pressure, inlet air temperature of 180 ± 5 o C, and outlet air temperature of 90 ± 5 o C with a feed flow rate of 450 mL/h. Drying chamber was a glass cylinder with a diameter of 35 cm and a height of 90 cm. Flow rate of drying air was about 0.1 m 3 /min. The dried powder was collected and stored in dark bottle, air tight containers at 4 o C until further analysis.

sections.heading: 2.4. Determination Of Water Activity And Bulk Density Of Powders
sections.text:
For determination of water activity of folic acid spray dried powders, we applied
instrumental analysis by Ecolab (USA). The bulk density ( bulk) of the powders was measured by weighing 1 g of sample and placing it in a 10 mL graduated cylinder. The cylinder was tapped by hand 100times and the bulk density was calculated as the ratio between the mass of powder contained in the cylinder and the volume occupied. [32]

sections.heading: 2.5. Droplet Size Measurement Of Emulsions
sections.text: Droplet size of nano- and double emulsions was analyzed using a dynamic light scattering method (Zetasizer Nano Zs, Malvern Instrument, Malvern, UK). To avoid multiple scattering, all samples diluted using 0.1% SDS.

sections.heading: 2.6. Scanning Electron Microscopy Of Encapsulated Powders
sections.text: The nano-encapsulated powders were sprinkled onto a two-sided adhesive tape and then coated with a thin layer of gold. Morphological features of particles were then observed by a field emission scanning electron microscope (S-4160 Cold Field-Emission SEM, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerated voltage of 320 kV and photographed at 6000.

sections.heading: 2.7. Statistical Analysis
sections.text:
The experiments (Table 1) were designed by Taguchi approach and the collected data were analyzed by Minitab software (Version 16, USA). On the basis of preliminary trials, the Taguchi orthogonal array design (L16) factors (independent and dependent) were selected, generated designs were prepared and their responses were evaluated (Table 1) for statistical optimization of formulations by investigating effects of major factors on responses with minimum number of formulation trials. All factors optimum conditions determined by estimating experimental conditions having minimum variability using orthogonal array analysis of variance (ANOVA) tables. The responses were analyzed to determine the significance of each factor by plotted against each level (main effects plot which reveals effect of each factor on responses). It also revealed the best optimum level of each factor which should be used to prepare an optimized formulation.
3. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization Of Nanoemulsions, Double Emulsions And Final Spray Dried
sections.text: Powders As shown in Fig. 1, produced nanoemulsions (W1/O) containing folic acid within the internal aqueous phase (W1) had a z-average of less than 100 nm which reveals they are thermodynamically stable emulsions. In fact, they were stable even after 3 months storage. These emulsions (W1/O) were applied as the internal phase of double emulsions (W1/O/W2) containing complex biopolymers of pectin-whey protein within the external (W2) phase which apparently resulted in bigger droplet sizes (Fig. 1) due to adsorption of biopolymers onto the interface of dispersed oil droplets. Considering spray dried powder particles containing encapsulated folic acid, a size range of about 2-30 µm was observed by SEM micrographs, as shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 3.2. Influence Of Independent Variables On Aw And Density Of Folic Acid
sections.text:
Powders Although, the design trails produced spray dried powders with good water activity and bulk density in the range of 0.272-0.457 and 286-421 kg/m 3 , respectively (Table 1), but selection of best formulation was difficult. Therefore, the responses (Y1 and Y2) obtained for each trial was analyzed based on independent factors. It also helps to establish the significance of each factor and their optimum levels for optimized formulation. The results for responses were interpreted by considering "lowest is the best" for better accuracy of measured data. The highest and lowest water activity was obtained for treatment No. 14 (0.457) and No. 3 (0.272), respectively. Regarding bulk density,
treatments 14 (421 kg/m 3 ) and 11 (286 kg/m 3 ) resulted in the maximum and minimum results, respectively. The “main effects plot” was drawn for each factor at different levels by taking levels as x-coordinates and water activity or bulk density as y-coordinates (Fig. 2 and 3). The plots could show effects of individual factors on water activity and bulk density of folic acid powders by different double emulsion formulations.
Moisture content is an important powder property, which is related to the drying efficiency, powder flowability, stickiness and storage stability due to its effect on glass transition and crystallization behavior. Furthermore, lower moisture content limits the ability of water to act as a plasticizer and to reduce the glass transition temperature. [33] Our results showed that different formulations affected the moisture content (water activity) of the particles. This variation in water activity could be attributed to the strength of the complex between pectin and WPC.
A prerequisite for the formation of electrostatic complexes is naturally the existence of opposing charges on the reacting species. Conventionally this is achieved by the utilization of an anionic polysaccharide (e.g., pectin) in combination with a protein (whey proteins in our case) bearing positive charge below its isoelectric point. [34,35] For polysaccharides such as pectin, the negative charge most commonly arises out of the presence of carboxyl moieties and for proteins, the positive charge normally is achievable below their isoelectric point. [36-38]
Our results (Fig. 2) showed that pectin concentration in the outer aqueous phase had a significant effect on the water activity of folic acid powders obtained from W1/O/W2 multiple emulsions. As it can be seen in Fig. 2, the lowest water activity of folic acid spray dried powders was obtained when the concentration of pectin and WPC was 0.5 and 4.0%, w/w, respectively. In other words, a weight ratio of 1.0:8.0 for pectin:WPC resulted in the best water activity. This finding shows indirectly that double emulsions prepared by 0.5% pectin and 4.0% WPC have a good stability and low moisture content, which results in the highest protection of folic acid. Similarly, Lutz et al (2009) working on double emulsion prepared with WPI-pectin found that a weight ratio of 4(WPI):0.5(pectin) came with the smallest droplet size and best stability of produced emulsions.
Fig. 3 shows the effect of different main factors on the bulk density of folic acid powders. Powders encapsulated with 1.5% pectin and 8.0% WPC exhibited a lower bulk density than others. Also, higher levels of pH and applying PGPR as the surfactant resulted in lower levels of bulk density which was desirable. According to Tonon et al. [39] bulk density of powders is related to molecular weight of wall materials. The heavier the material, more easily it accommodates into the spaces between the particles, occupying less space and resulting in higher bulk density values. Chegini & Ghobadian [40] reported that spray-dried powders with higher moisture contents tend to have a higher bulking weight, because of the presence of water, which is considerably denser than the dry solid. This behavior can be associated with the results observed in our study, because powders produced with higher levels of pectin and WPC showed higher water activity. Fig. 3
clearly shows that WPC had the highest influence on bulk density of folic acid spray dried powders.
Considering dispersed phase volume fraction (DPVF), in general, lower contents of the dispersed phase produced powders with lower bulk density. In this study, dispersed phase itself was a W/O nano- (or micro-) emulsion composed of surfactant (Span or PGPR), oil, and water containing folic acid. It can be concluded that increasing DPVF, results in an increase in the dispersed phase volume of double emulsions which could result in bigger dispersed droplets with lower emulsion stability [41] . Thus, folic acid molecules within the internal phase (dispersed droplets) could easily release and exit into external aqueous phase of final double emulsions without any protection from complex biopolymer layer of pectin-WPC and led to lower encapsulation efficiency.

sections.heading: 3.3. Most Important Factors And Their Interactions
sections.text:
Estimated model coefficients for means of water activity and bulk density and analysis of variance (ANOVA) for independent factors are given in Table 2 and 3, respectively.
As it is shown in Table 2 by the constant value, the grand average of water activity and bulk density for all treatments is equal to 0.371 and 343 kg/m 3 , respectively. When the influence of independent variables on the water activity and bulk density of folic acid powders is positive, the plus sign precedes their corresponding coefficients in the model and when it is negative, a minus sign comes before their coefficient which is consistent with the results of Fig. 3 and Fig. 4.
By looking at Table 3 and Fig. 4, it can be concluded that order of independent factors affecting the water activity of folic acid spray dried powders through double emulsions is (with pectin having the highest influence of 39.5%): Pectin pH Surfactant DPVF WPC
For bulk density of the powders, the order of independent factors is as below with WPC having the highest influence (29.6%) as shown in Table 3 and Fig. 4.
WPC pH Pectin DPVF Surfactant

sections.heading: 3.4. Optimization Results
sections.text:
By analysis of the results through Taguchi approach, it was found that the optimum conditions to have the lowest water activity (aw=0.229) were 0.5% pectin, 4.0% WPC, 10% dispersed phase, pH=8, with a PGPR micro-emulsion (Table 4). For obtaining the minimum bulk density of folic acid powders (245.45 kg/m 3 ), the optimum conditions were selected as 1.5% pectin, 8.0% WPC, 10% dispersed phase, pH=9, with a PGPR nano-emulsion (Table 4). These theoretical results were compatible to our experimental obtained results by a 93% correlation.
4. CONCLUSION
Fortification with folic acid has some possible limitations since added vitamin may be lost during processing and handling due to its high sensitivity to heat, oxidation, pH, and other environmental conditions. We evaluated a Taguchi approach for spray drying optimization of folic acid powders through W1/O/W2 multiple emulsions. It was found that the most affecting parameter on the water activity and bulk density of folic acid
powders was the pectin (39.5%) and WPC (29.6%) content, respectively. Finally, the optimum conditions to have the lowest water activity and bulk density for folic acid powders were determined as 0.5% pectin, 4.0% WPC, 10% dispersed phase, pH=8, with a PGPR micro-emulsion (for aw), and 1.5% pectin, 8.0% WPC, 10% dispersed phase, pH=9, with a PGPR nano-emulsion for bulk density).

metadata.abstractText: Research over recent decades has shown that inadequate folate concentrations may contribute to some disorders. Cereal flours have been a primary candidate for fortification by folic acid as they are consumed by most of the people but the main obstacle is destruction of this vitamin by the process and environmental deteriorating factors. So, it can be nano-encapsulated for protection and efficient delivery. Our main goal was to find the optimum conditions in spray drying of pectin-WPC (Whey Protein Concentrate) double emulsions containing folic acid. Five independent variables including pectin and WPC content, dispersed phase content, pH, and surfactant type of Span and PGPR (Poly Glycerol Poly Ricinoleate) were considered along with water activity (aw) and bulk density as the main responses. The experiment design was performed by Taguchi approach and 16 treatments were determined. The grand average of aw and bulk density for folic acid powders was approximately 0.371 and 343 kg/m 3 , respectively. The main effect analysis with Taguchi technique revealed that pectin content was the most important factor affecting aw (39.5%) and WPC had the minimum influence (6%). In terms of bulk density, it was found that the most important parameter was WPC (29.6%)
